article.headline: Trump supporters say they donât view his contracting the coronavirus as a cautionary tale
article.body: CANTON, Ohio (AP) â As an infected President Donald Trump urged Americans not to fear the virus that has killed more than 1 million people worldwide, many of his supporters were already in sync with that message. In interviews with Republican voters at Trump events and campaign offices, very few saw the presidentâs illness as a cautionary tale. None said they would change their personal approach to masks or distancing, and many expressed a confidence that the disease was less dangerous than advertised. In Ohio, a âWomen for Trumpâ group gathered indoors â many maskless and not distanced â to pray for the presidentâs recovery. In Nevada, a Reno businessman dismissed the threat of the pandemic as âoverplayed.â Nearby, another Trump backer shrugged off any second thoughts about having cheered at a Trump campaign event last week as part of a maskless crowd. Capitol Report:Trump calls contracting coronavirus âblessing from Godâ in latest video âI think most of us have reached the realization that, at some point, weâre probably going catch it, and have to deal with it anyway,â Ken Gray, a county commissioner from Dayton, Nev., shortly before the president returned to the White House after three days of treatment for COVID-19 at Walter Reed National Military Medical Center. Trumpâs âdonât be afraidâ take-away is infuriating public health experts â who note that basic prevention measures do work contain the spread of the deadly virus. Itâs also angering family members of those who have died. But for many of Trumpâs supporters, the president was merely adopting an attitude they expect, and they themselves reflect, when it comes to the pandemic. They view Trumpâs infection as almost inevitable. Some were amazed heâd made it this far before getting sick. âItâs October and heâs just now getting it,â said 18-year-old Taylor Adams, a first-time voter, at the womenâs meeting in Ohio. Adams even commended the president for not contracting the disease sooner. âI think that heâs definitely going to pull through. But Iâm not surprised that he did get it eventually.â The comments were a testament to the power of Trumpâs messaging, widely seen as misleading by public health experts. Throughout the pandemic, the presidentâs public portrayal of the virus has been rosier than reality. Heâs routinely brushed off the severity of the outbreak and dismissed expert advice on mask wearing and social distancing. On Tuesday, he compared the virus to the seasonal flu, suggesting it was something that should be âlearned to live with.â Donât miss:Trump reportedly asked doctors at Walter Reed National Military Medical Center to sign nondisclosure agreements when he made a surprise visit to the hospital last year. Hereâs what you need to know before signing an NDA In fact, COVID-19 has proven to be a more potent killer than the flu, particularly among older people, and has shown indications of having long-term impacts on the health of younger people it infects. Trump acknowledged to journalist Bob Woodward that he âwanted to always play it downâ because he did not want to cause panic. Among many supporters, that appears to have worked. Trump voters interviewed this week were almost blase about their presidentâs health scare, describing it as an unavoidable part of his work and travel schedule. âI donât find it surprising. The president has spent much of the year around the country, with supporters, campaigning for another four years,â said Ohio resident Brenda Parsons, 58. As women supporting Trump gathered at an office building in Canton, a battleground area in the stateâs northeast, few wore masks. They sat closer than the recommended six feet apart. They posed for photos with a life-size cutout of the president and a giant mural of a bald eagle wearing a âMake America Great Againâ hat, and chanted âfour more years!â “ âFrom Day 1, Iâve thought the whole virus has been overplayed and used as a political tool.â ” â Reno, Nev., businessman They prayed for the president and first lady Melania Trump, who contracted the disease along with others in the White House. âI pray and know the presidentâs positive mind set combined with his faith in Jesus is what will help him pull through this,â Parsons said. Itâs unclear exactly how Trump got infected. He has traveled steadily for weeks for his reelection campaign, sometimes holding events indoors, where experts say the virus is more likely to spread. The White House required testing for anyone in close proximity to the president, but masks and social distancing practices were lax. Even now, masks at the White House are a matter of âpersonal choiceâ except for National Security Council staffers, who are required to wear them. Trumpâs supporters donât view these practices as irresponsible and were largely quick to dismiss the level of risk involved. Kathy Burke, a Reno retiree who dropped by her local Trump campaign office Monday afternoon to pick up more campaign signs, was wearing a Trump face mask, a precaution she said she already took before Trumpâs diagnosis. She too saw the presidentâs infection as inevitable. âAnybody could get it. I could get it,â Burke said. Rick Zirpolo, a Reno businessman who eschewed a mask outside, said he had no qualms with the way Trump has portrayed or confronted the deadly threat. âFrom Day 1, Iâve thought the whole virus has been overplayed and used as a political tool,â he said. Zirpolo praised the president for briefly leaving the hospital over the weekend for a drive-by to wave to supporters, despite his infection. And he said Trump was right to leave the hospital Monday to return to the White House. âI think itâs outstanding because it shows his commitment to the nation,â he said. Across the country, in Newberry, S.C., Scott Gardner, a teacher and coach, felt differently. He didnât blame the president for having contracted COVID-19, given its pervasive nature and ease of transmission. But the 50-year-old who supported Trump in 2016 and planned to vote for him again this year, hoped the president would change his behavior. The experience should serve as a âwakeup callâ to employ more social distancing and masking, especially in a crowd. âI guess it should be an eye opener,â said Gardner. âBut if youâre going to get out of your basement, youâre going to have a chance to catch it.â
